contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Coin of Vonones I of Parthia.jpg|thumb|300px|Coin of Vonones I from the mint at [[Ecbatana]]. The Greek inscription on the obverse reads ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ (king). The reverse shows [[Nike (mythology)|Nike]] with a palm. The inscription reads ΒΑϹΙΛΕΥϹ ΟΝΩΝΗϹ ΝΕΙΚΗϹΑϹ ΑΡΤΑΒΑΝ[ΟΝ].]] '''Vonones I of Parthia''' ({{lang-fa|ونون یکم}}), (ΟΝΩΝΗΣ on his coins) ruled the [[Parthia|Parthian Empire]] from about 8 to 12 [[AD]]. He was the eldest son of [[Phraates IV of Parthia]] (ruled c. 37–2 BC) and was sent to [[Rome]] as a hostage in the 20s BC as surety for a [[treaty]] his father made with [[Augustus]].<ref>Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#1|2.1]]</ref> After the assassination of [[Orodes III of Parthia|Orodes III]] in about the year 6 [[AD]], the Parthians applied to Augustus for a new King from the [[Arsacid Empire|house of Arsaces]].<ref name="ref1">Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#2|2.2]]</ref> Augustus sent them Vonones I, but he could not maintain himself as King; he had been educated as a [[Ancient Rome|Roman]], and was despised by the Parthian nobility as a slave of the Romans.<ref name="ref1"/> Another member of the Arsacid house, [[Artabanus III (of Parthia)|Artabanus III]] (ruled c. 10–38), who was living among the [[Dahan (people)|Dahan]] nomads in the east of Parthia, was invited to the throne. In a civil war he defeated and expelled Vonones I. The coins of Vonones I date from 8 to 12 AD and bear the inscription "King Vonones, conqueror of Artabanus" commemorating a temporary victory over his rival. Those of Artabanus II begin in the year 10. In about the year 12 Vonones I fled into [[Roman Armenia|Armenia]] and became King there.<ref>Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#3|2.3]]</ref> But Artabanus II demanded his deposition, and as Augustus did not wish to begin a war with the Parthians he removed Vonones I into [[Syria (Roman province)|Syria]], where he was kept in custody, though in a kingly style.<ref>Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#4|2.4]]</ref> Later he was moved to [[Cilicia]],<ref>Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#58|2.58]]</ref> and when he tried to escape in about 19 AD, he was killed by his guards.<ref>Tacitus, The Annals [[s:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 2#68|2.68]]</ref> {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[Arsacid Empire|Arsacid dynasty]]||Unknown||19}} {{s-bef|before=[[Orodes III of Parthia|Orodes III]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of kings of Persia|Great King (Shah) of Parthia]]|years=8–12}} {{s-aft|after=[[Artabanus III (of Parthia)|Artabanus III]]}} {{end}} ==References== * {{1911}} * Hon. Ana. 5, 9. * [[Josephus]], ''Antiquities of the Jews'', xviii, 2, 4. * [[Tacitus]], ''[[Annals (Tacitus)|Annals]]'', [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+2.4 ii, 4], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+2.58 58], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+2.68 68]. ==Notes== <references/> {{Parthian kings}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vonones 01 Of Parthia}} [[Category:1st-century BC births]] [[Category:19 deaths]] [[Category:Parthian kings]] [[Category:1st-century monarchs in the Middle East]] [[Category:Roman client rulers]]
